Timeline

Below is a predicted timeline for the rest of our project. We will update it with what we get finished with

Dates Week 1 (3) Week 2 (2) Week 3 (3) Week 4 (2) Week 5 (2) Week 6 (4, thanksgiving break) Week 7 (2) Week 8 (2) Week 9 (3) Week 10 (3) Week 11 (2) Week 12 (2) Week 13 (2) Week 14 (2) Week 15 (3) Week 16 (2) Week 17 (3) Week 18 (2) Week 19 (3) Week 20 (2) Stretch Goals
Ty Install the Arduino CLI on Windows and Mac. Get AudioTools for Arduino to build. Fine-tune Espeak settings for optimal output of math content. Finish the math handler outline. Try to deploy the code to the prototype. Write a configuration system that allows for key remapping. Automate usage of the Arduino CLI for accessible deployment. Deploy code to the prototype. Finish the basic mathematical functions (e.g. addition, multiplication, etc). Write code for many more math functions. Continue improving the config provider, making remapping keys easier and possibly allowing for text-to-speech configuration. Improve upon trigonometric functions. Test the code on the hardware again. Explore audio effects such as EQ for enhancing speech quality. Implement necessary fixes for battery life. More bug fixing. Fix anything necessary to make the code work on the protype. Polish the code. Make any necessary optimizations for battery life. Make the table board. Replace arrows with 3DS Circle Pad to navigate. Would require both hardware and software changes to be implimented. This would allow better control of the graphing utilities
Install any needed C/C++ tooling Build Espeak for Arduino and try to test it. Write a text_to_speech provider class that wraps Espeak in a very friendly way. Write a basic button mapper that allows for mapping of buttons to C++ functions. Tune the code to make it properly work given the limited resources available. Add many more math functions. Clean up the code. Test the code on the hardware again. Begin researching more advanced mathematical functions (starting with trigonometry). Perfect the sign wave generator. Continue tuning Espeak settings for optimal math reading. More code cleanup. Work more on the mathematical functions. Implement more math functions. Fix any bugs in the implementation of math functions. Use my sign wave generator to give the buttons even mroe feedback. Optimize the code by removing unnecessary dynamic memory allocations and inlining loops. Test final code on the prototype. Begin work on presentation. Finish presentation
Bootstrap the GitHub repository. Start writing an outline for the math handler. Start work on a basic sign wave generator for generating graphs. Polish website for public viewing.
Grant Initial physical development prototype Create circuit design for full size prototype Create Case Design Create buttons Create functional prototype Replace arrows with 3DS Circle Pad to navigate. Would require both hardware and software changes to be implimented. This would allow better control of the graphing utilities
Test ESP32's to ensure they work Research how button matrices with microcontrollers need to be implemented on the circuit level Begin creation of full prototype on breadboard Test new prototype button input and speaker output Start with soldering and assembling prototype Learn about creating schematics for devices and the software required Build schematic on breadboard Modify schematic design Test interoperability with calculator software Research basics of solidworks Make a practice part to learn how to use solidworks Make a prototype case with pcb, battery, and other components to ensure it fits Test assemble the part Research ways to use button design to communicate function with braille Refine design of braille Solder and assemble the ordered PCB with required components Modify software to run on new prototype Print out case and buttons and assemble Test battery life and fix as needed Start presentation
Research audio output on ESP32 with the internal DAC Start with breadboard experimentation of button matrices and confirm that it works Finish, test, and modify breadboard prototype Create initial low level software for interfacing with the calculator program Create a general sketch of the final product with button locations divided into groups Continue Learning about Schematics software Test all inputs and outputs to ensure they work Create initial software for interpreting button presses Research PCB Creation Continue learning solidworks Sketch out 2d view of calculator Print out test to see if there are any mistakes to fix Finish part assembly Create and print test braille in solidworks Create buttons with different shapes and test how well they fit on buttons and in the case Finish assembly Identify issues with it and fix low level software if needed sand anything that doesnt go together Write docmunetation for design finish presentation and posterboard
Experiment with a speaker for basic audio output tests Make breadboard prototype on protoboard soldered to make it able to be used for software development Start a creation of the schematic of the board Convert Schematic to PCB and order PCB and Components Finish learning solidworks Refine buttons design and fit Test calculator to ensure high build quality Write documentation for servicing
Finish schematic including documentation
